title: Tolerance Intervals
label1: Select a distribution function that fits the data best
variableSelcted: Select a variable (observed data) to analyze
x: The number of defective (or acceptable) units in the sample
m: The quantity produced in future groups
P: Minimum (specify a value between 0 and 1) percentage of population in interval
side: 1-sided or 2-sided tolerance interval is required (type 1 or 2)
method: The method for calculating the k-factors (only applicable for Normal, Log Normal, Gamma)

help.title: Tolerance Intervals
help.body:
Description
Function to compute tolerance intervals

For the detail help - use R help(package = 'tolerance'), help(normtol.int, package = tolerance), help(exttol.int, package = tolerance)

The method for calculating the k-factors

The method for calculating the k-factors is only applicable for Normal, Log Normal, and Gamma distribution.

The k-factor for the 1-sided tolerance intervals is performed exactly and thus is the same for the chosen method. "HE" is the Howe method and is often viewed as being extremely accurate,
even for small sample sizes. "HE2" is a second method due to Howe, which performs similarly to the Weissberg-Beatty
method, but is computationally simpler. "WBE" is the Weissberg-Beatty method (also called the Wald-Wolfowitz method),
which performs similarly to the first Howe method for larger sample sizes. "ELL" is the Ellison correction to the
Weissberg-Beatty method when f is appreciably larger than n^2. A warning message is displayed if f is not larger
than n^2. "KM" is the Krishnamoorthy-Mathew approximation to the exact solution, which works well for larger sample sizes.
"EXACT" computes the k-factor exactly by finding the integral solution to the problem via the integrate function.
Note the computation time of this method is largely determined by m. "OCT" is the Owen approach to compute the k-factor
when controlling the tails so that there is not more than (1-P)/2 of the data in each tail of the distribution.

To try this, you may use the sample dataset file called tolerance.xlsx. Open the file in the data grid with file open menu
Choose ND to variable(observed..),
